sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In this tutorial, you’ll learn how Ethereum keypairs are generated and how public addresses are derived from mnemonic seed phrases using Python. This guide is intended for educational and development purposes.

sections.title: Security Warning
sections.content: Never use real wallet seed phrases or private keys in test scripts or shared environments. Always use randomly generated or test-only mnemonic phrases when learning or experimenting. Exposing real keys can lead to permanent loss of funds.

sections.title: Prerequisites
sections.content: Make sure you have Python 3 installed on your system. You will also need several cryptography-related libraries commonly used in Ethereum development.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content: You can clone the example repository to follow along locally. This repository demonstrates how key derivation works using Python libraries.

sections.title: Running the Script
sections.content: Once the dependencies are installed, you can run the script from the terminal.

sections.title: Providing a Mnemonic Phrase
sections.content: When prompted, enter a test mnemonic phrase. The script will derive a private key and generate the corresponding Ethereum address.
sections.code:
Enter mnemonic phrase: example test seed phrase only
Ethereum Address: <derived-address>
Private Key: <derived-private-key>

sections.title: Understanding the Output
sections.content: The Ethereum address is derived from the public key, which itself is derived from the private key. The private key must be kept secret at all times, while the address can be shared publicly to receive funds.

sections.title: How Keypairs Work in Ethereum
sections.content: Ethereum uses elliptic curve cryptography (secp256k1). A private key generates a public key, and the Ethereum address is computed by hashing the public key. Libraries such as eth-account handle these cryptographic steps safely.

sections.title: Summary and Next Steps
sections.content: You’ve learned how Ethereum keypairs are generated using Python and how mnemonic phrases are used for deterministic wallet creation. Next, you can explore signing transactions, interacting with smart contracts, or integrating key management into secure applications.
